body:
All kinds of capabilities that allow removing noise or automating the inference of experiment attributes are most meaningful. Particularly the latter is important...it will keep paying dividends as we keep automating/abstracting.  

How do you foresee it working? Would it be something like lr_normalizer or hidden_layers i.e. a stand-alone utility, or something more built-in? Generally the preference is to have anything with "magics"  (e.g. inference of attributes >> making changes automatically) as utils. 

Related with that, in the v.0.5.0 namespace things like this will be tidy/accessible under `ta.utils` from where it can then be used directly.

The way I envissioned it was a parameter to scan called premutation_filter or something like that. The parameter would expect a function that takes a param object in the same format as the model function and returns True or False depending on whether we want to keep it or not. How does that sounds?

issue.title: Add ability to filter out unwanted premutations

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
I propose to fix https://github.com/autonomio/talos/issues/223 by this pull request

The code is used like

    talos.Scan(
        ...
        ,premutation_filter=lambda p: p['hidden_layers']<3 or p['first_neuron']<10)

I have tested locally but not added any tests

body:
I spent some time testing this yesterday, and cleaned it up a little https://github.com/autonomio/talos/commit/9787ff150e185ff5a51a25c69978d2c50621ce79 as well as moving it to its own function under parameters, but I think it belongs to reducers so it might end up there. Because it basically serves the purpose of reducing the sample. This leads to an important point. 

It seems to me that right now what happens is that this over-rides grid downsampling. This means that if both `permutation_filter` and `grid_downsample`are applied, `permutation_filter` makes whatever `grid_dowsample` have done null. 

### Useful background information

Basically the Talos use design is as follows: 

**level-1)** setup the experiment >> creates the experiment
**level-2)** decide a random method to decrease grid size >> creates the permutation grid and index
**level-3)** apply reducers  to further decrease the grid size  >> edits the index

The way a reducer works is that it goes to the current results, and identifies what is contributing performance / lack of performance and outputs a parameter value, parameter values, or combinations of parameter values. So far a lot of the work have been in preparation to allow building of a comprehensive library of known and unknown optimization/selection strategies which plug in at level-3.

As I can see, permutation_filter is on one hand a means to explicitly state reduction criteria and apply it right at the beginning of the experiment, and on the other it provides a meaningful interface to accept outputs from all reducers, find the index numbers from the current grid, and block those index numbers from the current index. 

Once we figure out how to fit permutation_filter to this bigger picture, the "over-riding" issue mentioned above is also automatically resolved. The key point is to retain the design flow: 

- create experiment (Scan)
- create grid and index (grid_downsample)
- edit the index to block values (everything else)

@JohanMollevik What do you think?

First if it voids the result of the downsample then that is sa bug, the design I aimed at was to return exactly as many results that the downsample would have returned.

Right, I was viewing it as a downsampling step where I change the shape of the premutation hypercube to only consider some parts of it. The reason I did it like that is to respect round_limit and not run fewer iterations than specified, suppose that I feel I need 200 ierations to get reliable statistics I would like it to run exactly 200 times and not less. If I on the other hand did a grid downsample then the current reducer design makes sense.

Are my way of looking at it like a downsampling step workable or do you want it to change to be more of a reducer?
@JohanMollevik  Thanks for clarifying, that helps me to think about the taxonomy/levels more clearly. I will open a new thread as the topic is broader than this feature...let's see where we end up :)

issue.title: Experiments, Limits and Reducers (taxonomy / architecture discussion)

repository.name: talos
repository.description: Hyperparameter Optimization for TensorFlow, Keras and PyTorch

issue.body:
Related and in part initiated by #223. 

The highest level, we have: 

- experiment
- limits
- reducers

First, let's define _experiment_ as what we setup in `Scan()`, _limits_ as various procedures that are used for limiting the extent of the _experiment_ by some input, and _reducers_ as various procedurers

**LIMITERS:**

  - limit by sample (e.g. no more than 1% of all)
  - limit by round (e.g. no more than 100 permutations)
  - limit by time (e.g. start the last permutation at 8 am)
  - limit by metric (e.g. stop when 'f1_score > 0.9)

Am I missing something here?

**REDUCERS:**

A reducer would be anything that can be applied within a preset window into the experiment, where the intention is to identify poorly performing parameters, which then are used to reduce the remaining permutation grid. 

The three levels - _experiment_ (level-1), _limits_ (level-2), and _reducers_ (level-3) - require a basis on which they can communicate i.e. the parameter grid. The experiment sets the boundary, limit is used to limit the experiment to a subset of the original boundary, and reducer is used to keep further limiting the boundary in an arbitrary manner throughout the experiment. 

Thoughts/questions?

body:
This appears to be handled so closing here. Also, there is now a new reducer `local_strategy` which allows you to make changes to the params dictionary while the experiment is running. This is particularly powerful together with `ExperimentLogCallback` which gives you the epoch-by-epoch training data during the experiment on local. 

Closing here.
